titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert Thorney and Jemima Frost Craft marriage certificate 1979.005
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-28 18:52:25 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Robert Thorney and Jemima Frost Craft marriage certificate
did.abstract: Marriage certificate of Robert Thorney Craft and Jemima Frost of Queens County, signed by Cadwallader Colden, Lieutenant Governor and Commander in Chief of the Province of New York under King George III. The certificate is dated 1764. Robert Thorney Craft was a joiner by trade.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1979.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Robert Thorney Craft was a joiner by trade. He married Jemima Frost in 1764.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert Thorney and Jemima Frost Craft marriage certificate, 1764, 1979.005; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marriage certificate of Robert Thorney Craft and Jemima Frost of Queens County, signed by Cadwallader Colden, Lieutenant Governor and Commander in Chief of the Province of New York under King George III. The certificate is dated 1764.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
